ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about anthropological and archaeological issues relating to the Eurasian Steppe, from analyzing when horse riding developed in the region to understanding how the nomadic pastoralists of the region have historically related to their surrounding sedentary societies. The course really reinforced how important a role archaeology and anthropology have even in current-day issues, which is an idea I can carry forward into my studies in other fields.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved that this course was small, because it allowed me to really engage in class discussions and I enjoyed the reading selections for the course. I also really appreciated the open-ended nature of the final paper, which allowed me to explore a topic I was interested in, while applying what we learned in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I'd recommend this course because Professor Honeychurch is a great professor, and the course allows you to dive into the topic even if you don't have a strong background in it. It really changed my understanding of Eurasian Steppe peoples, and nomadic pastoralists in general.
